summary: Chapter 15 of "Atomic Habits" discusses the cardinal rule of behavior change: making habits satisfying to ensure repetition. It begins with Stephen Luby's public health work in Karachi, Pakistan, a city with poor sanitation and widespread illness. Luby's team promoted hand washing but found that knowledge wasn't enough; consistency was the real issue. Partnering with Procter & Gamble, they introduced Safeguard soap, a premium soap that made hand washing more enjoyable. This led to a significant improvement in children's health, with rates of diarrhea, pneumonia, and skin infections decreasing. Six years later, over 95% of households in the intervention group maintained hand-washing stations, demonstrating the power of habituation through satisfying experiences. The chapter emphasizes that we are more likely to repeat behaviors when they are satisfying. Feelings of pleasure signal to the brain that a behavior is worth repeating. Examples like Wrigley's flavored gum and flavored toothpaste illustrate how adding small bits of immediate reinforcement can make a product satisfying and drive consumption. Conversely, if an experience is not satisfying, we have little reason to repeat it. The chapter states what is rewarded is repeated and what is punished is avoided. It highlights the importance of immediate satisfaction in completing the habit loop. It discusses the concept of time inconsistency, where the brain values the present more than the future, leading to problems when the consequences of bad habits are delayed while the rewards are immediate. This explains why people engage in behaviors like smoking and overeating, despite knowing the long-term risks. The chapter points out that with bad habits, the immediate outcome feels good, but the ultimate outcome feels bad, while with good habits, it is the reverse. The chapter updates the cardinal rule of behavior change to what is immediately rewarded is repeated and what is immediately punished is avoided. It notes that people are wired to chase quick hits of satisfaction, and the road less traveled is the road of delayed gratification, which often leads to bigger payoffs. While most people know delaying gratification is wise, they often struggle to do so. The chapter suggests training oneself to delay gratification by adding immediate pleasure to good habits and immediate pain to bad ones. The key to sticking with a habit is to feel successful, even in a small way, and to make the ending of the habit satisfying. The best approach is to use reinforcement, which involves using an immediate reward to increase the rate of a behavior.

evidence.verbatim_text: [03:53:47,115,03:53:50,197] Chapter 15, the cardinal rule of behavior change.
[03:53:53,020,03:54:01,507] In the late 1990s, a public health worker named Stephen Luby left his hometown of Omaha, Nebraska, and bought a one-way ticket to Karachi, Pakistan.
[03:54:02,588,03:54:08,073] Karachi was one of the most populous cities in the world. By 1998, over 9 million people called it home.
[03:54:22,026,03:54:25,108] But Karachi was also one of the least livable cities in the world.
[03:54:26,049,03:54:30,091] Over 60% of Karachi's residents lived in squatter settlements and slums.
[03:54:38,867,03:54:42,969] There was no waste removal system, no electricity grid, no clean water supply.
[03:54:56,033,03:54:59,074] The unsanitary conditions led to widespread illness and disease.
[03:54:59,735,03:55:04,737] Contaminated water sources caused epidemics of diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
[03:55:15,145,03:55:18,708] It was this public health crisis that had brought Stephen Luby to Pakistan.
[03:55:20,269,03:55:27,935] Luby and his team realized that in an environment with poor sanitation, the simple habit of washing your hands could make a real difference in the health of the residents.
[03:55:28,835,03:55:32,618] But they soon discovered that many people were already aware that hand washing was important.
[03:55:33,258,03:55:37,722] And yet, despite this knowledge, many residents were washing their hands in a haphazard fashion.
[03:55:47,646,03:55:52,874] Everyone said hand washing was important, but few people made a habit out of it. The problem wasn't knowledge.
[03:55:53,195,03:55:54,517] The problem was consistency.
[03:55:55,746,03:56:00,789] That was when Luby and his team partnered with Procter & Gamble to supply the neighborhood with Safeguard soap.
[03:56:01,649,03:56:05,951] Compared to your standard bar of soap, using Safeguard was a much more enjoyable experience.
[03:56:06,812,03:56:09,713] In Pakistan, Safeguard was a premium soap, Luby told me.
[03:56:13,975,03:56:18,217] The soap foamed easily and people were able to lather their hands with suds. It smelled great.
[03:56:18,738,03:56:21,139] Instantly, hand washing became slightly more pleasurable.
[03:56:46,323,03:56:50,046] Within months, the researchers saw a rapid shift in the health of children in the neighborhood.
[03:56:50,961,03:56:57,964] The rate of diarrhea fell by 52%, pneumonia by 48%, and impetigo, a bacterial skin infection, by 35%.

[03:57:06,348,03:57:15,092] Over 95% of households who had been given the soap for free and encouraged to wash their hands had a hand-washing station with soap and water available when our study team visited.

[03:57:15,973,03:57:24,206] We had not given any soap to the intervention group for over five years, but during the trial, they had become so habituated to wash their hands that they had maintained the practice.
[03:57:25,227,03:57:30,035] It was a powerful example of the fourth and final law of behavior change. Make it satisfying.
[03:57:31,478,03:57:37,002] We are more likely to repeat a behavior when the experience is satisfying. This is entirely logical.

[03:57:37,462,03:57:46,348] Feelings of pleasure, even minor ones like washing your hands with soap that smells nice and lathers well, are signals that tell the brain, this feels good, do this again next time.
[03:57:47,268,03:57:52,832] Pleasure teaches your brain that a behavior is worth remembering and repeating. Take the story of chewing gum.
[03:57:53,592,03:58:00,637] Chewing gum had been sold commercially throughout the 1800s, but it wasn't until Wrigley launched in 1891 that it became a worldwide habit.
[03:58:06,426,03:58:13,109] Wrigley revolutionized the industry by adding flavors like spearmint and juicy fruit, which made the product flavorful and fun to use.
[03:58:23,094,03:58:29,318] Tasty flavors and the feeling of a fresh mouth provided little bits of immediate reinforcement and made the product satisfying to use.
[03:58:30,527,03:58:34,531] Consumption skyrocketed and Wrigley became the largest chewing gum company in the world.
[03:58:35,932,03:58:37,573] Toothpaste had a similar trajectory.
[03:58:38,414,03:58:43,658] Manufacturers enjoyed great success when they added flavors like spearmint, peppermint, and cinnamon to their products.
[03:58:47,222,03:58:51,866] They simply create a clean mouth feel and make the experience of brushing your teeth more pleasurable.
[03:59:01,007,03:59:05,109] Conversely, if an experience is not satisfying, we have little reason to repeat it.
[03:59:22,707,03:59:27,931] Stories like these are evidence of the cardinal rule of behavior change. What is rewarded is repeated.
[03:59:28,272,03:59:29,673] What is punished is avoided.
[03:59:30,633,03:59:36,198] You learn what to do in the future based on what you were rewarded for doing or punished for doing in the past.
[03:59:37,059,03:59:40,481] Positive emotions cultivate habits. Negative emotions destroy them.
[03:59:41,802,03:59:49,769] The first three laws of behavior change, make it obvious, make it attractive, and make it easy, increase the odds that a behavior will be performed this time.
[03:59:50,784,03:59:56,768] The fourth law of behavior change, make it satisfying, increases the odds that a behavior will be repeated next time.
[04:00:03,793,04:00:06,595] We are looking for immediate satisfaction.
[04:00:20,884,04:02:24,546] Behavioral economists refer to this tendency as time inconsistency.
[04:02:25,047,04:02:31,931] That is, the way your brain evaluates rewards is inconsistent across time. You value the present more than the future.
[04:02:40,957,04:02:44,540] But occasionally, our bias toward instant gratification causes problems.
[04:03:02,536,04:03:06,339] The consequences of bad habits are delayed, while the rewards are immediate.
[04:03:20,884,04:03:26,091] Disease and infection won't show up for days or weeks, even years. Every habit produces multiple outcomes across time.
[04:03:29,673,04:03:34,056] With our bad habits, the immediate outcome usually feels good, but the ultimate outcome feels bad.
[04:03:34,976,04:03:40,059] With good habits, it is the reverse. The immediate outcome is unenjoyable, but the ultimate outcome feels good.

[04:03:41,111,04:03:52,035] The French economist, Frédéric Bastiat, explained the problem clearly when he wrote, it almost always happens that when the immediate consequence is favorable, the later consequences are disastrous, and vice versa.
[04:03:53,015,04:03:56,797] Often, the sweeter the first fruit of a habit, the more bitter are its later fruits.
[04:03:57,997,04:04:03,219] Put another way, the cost of your good habits are in the present. The cost of your bad habits are in the future.
[04:04:04,039,04:04:08,881] The brain's tendency to prioritize the present moment means you can't rely on good intentions.
[04:04:40,666,04:04:47,692] As a general rule, the more immediate pleasure you get from an action, the more strongly you should question whether it aligns with your long-term goals.
[04:05:20,015,04:05:27,097] With a fuller understanding of what causes our brain to repeat some behaviors and avoid others, let's update the cardinal rule of behavior change.
[04:05:27,698,04:05:32,559] What is immediately rewarded is repeated. What is immediately punished is avoided.
[04:05:33,860,04:05:37,781] Our preference for instant gratification reveals an important truth about success.
[04:05:38,541,04:05:42,943] Because of how we are wired, most people will spend all day chasing quick hits of satisfaction.
[04:05:43,840,04:05:46,622] The road less traveled is the road of delayed gratification.
[04:05:47,242,04:05:52,045] If you're willing to wait for the rewards, you'll face less competition and often get a bigger payoff.

[04:05:59,874,04:06:10,365] People who are better at delaying gratification have higher SAT scores, lower levels of substance abuse, lower likelihood of obesity, better responses to stress, and superior social skills.
[04:06:23,691,04:06:30,514] At some point, success in nearly every field requires you to ignore the immediate reward in favor of a delayed reward.
[04:06:31,614,04:06:35,676] Here's the problem. Most people know that delaying gratification is the wise approach.
[04:06:44,299,04:06:50,722] Thankfully, it's possible to train yourself to delay gratification, but you need to work with the grain of human nature, not against it.
[04:06:51,528,04:06:58,894] The best way to do this is to add a little bit of immediate pleasure to the habits that pay off in the long run and a little bit of immediate pain to the ones that don't.
[04:07:01,256,04:07:09,963] How to Turn Instant Gratification to Your Advantage The vital thing in getting a habit to stick is to feel successful, even if it's in a small way.
[04:07:11,064,04:07:15,588] The feeling of success is a signal that your habit paid off and that the work was worth the effort.
[04:07:16,669,04:07:20,052] In a perfect world, the reward for a good habit is the habit itself.
[04:07:20,817,04:07:25,800] But in the real world, good habits tend to feel worthwhile only after they have provided you with something.
[04:07:26,521,04:07:28,142] Early on, it's all sacrifice.
[04:07:42,698,04:07:47,644] In the beginning, you need a reason to stay on track. This is why immediate rewards are essential.
[04:07:48,045,04:07:51,489] They keep you excited while the delayed rewards accumulate in the background.
[04:07:52,650,04:07:57,632] What we're really talking about here, when we're discussing immediate rewards, is the ending of a behavior.
[04:08:03,355,04:08:05,616] You want the ending of your habit to be satisfying.
[04:08:06,216,04:08:13,379] The best approach is to use reinforcement, which refers to the process of using an immediate reward to increase the rate of a behavior.
